title: Paper_217
abstract: pmc BMC Cancer BMC Cancer 16 bmccanc BMC Cancer 1471-2407 BMC PMC12487558 PMC12487558.1 12487558 12487558 41034725 10.1186/s12885-025-14975-3 14975 1 Research Sweets consumption and breast cancer risk among women in yemen: a matched case control study Al-Taj Mansour Abdu taj.fsis@gmail.com https://ror.org/04hcvaf32 grid.412413.1 0000 0001 2299 4112 Department of Community Medicine, Faculty of Medicine and Health Sciences, Sana’a University, 30 9 2025 2025 25 478185 1495 13 6 2025 2 9 2025 30 09 2025 02 10 2025 03 10 2025 © The Author(s) 2025 2025 https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ Open Access http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ Background Breast cancer among women is the most common type of cancer in Yemen. The risk factors contributing to this trend have not been thoroughly studied, creating challenges in prevention strategies. Methods A hospital-based matched case-control study was conducted to identify the association between sweet food consumption and breast cancer among women in Yemen. A total of 127 women newly diagnosed with breast cancer (cases) and 254 women who had never been diagnosed with any type of cancer (controls) were enrolled. The controls were matched to the cases based on age ± 2 years, place of residence (urban or rural), and menopausal status. Conditional logistic regression was used to accommodate the matching, and crude odds ratios (COR), adjusted odds ratio (AOR), and 95% confidence intervals (CI) were estimated. The level of significance was set at a p-value of less than 0.05. Results Women who consumed sweets three to seven times per week (AOR, 5.27; 95% CI 2.35–11.79) or one to two times per week (AOR, 2.98; 95% CI 1.39–6.37) were almost five and three times more likely to have breast cancer, respectively. Similarly, those who consumed pan-fried bread three to seven times per week (AOR, 2.17; 95% CI 1.02–4.61) or one to two times per week (AOR, 2.12; 95% CI 1.14–3.92) were nearly two times more likely to have breast cancer than those who consumed it rarely or never. Additionally, having a family member with a history of any kind of cancer increased the risk of developing breast cancer by more than twofold (AOR, 2.19; 95% CI 1.27–3.78). Conclusion Health education campaigns are urgently needed to raise awareness among the population about the risks associated with frequent consumption of sweets and pan-fried bread in relation to breast cancer development among women. Keywords Breast cancer Risk factors Dietary habits Sweet Women Yemen pmc-status-qastatus 0 pmc-status-live yes pmc-status-embargo no pmc-status-released yes pmc-prop-open-access yes pmc-prop-olf no pmc-prop-manuscript no pmc-prop-legally-suppressed no pmc-prop-has-pdf yes pmc-prop-has-supplement no pmc-prop-pdf-only no pmc-prop-suppress-copyright no pmc-prop-is-real-version no pmc-prop-is-scanned-article no pmc-prop-preprint no pmc-prop-in-epmc yes issue-copyright-statement © BioMed Central Ltd., part of Springer Nature 2025 Introduction Breast cancer is one of the most common cancers worldwide and a public health threat in many countries. About 99% of breast cancer cases are found in women, while only 0.5–1% occur in men [ 1 1 2 3 4 7 8 Dietary habits are key determinants of human health, influencing the risk of various diseases and health conditions [ 9 10 11 12 13 14 15 16 Increased consumption of milk [ 17 18 19 20 21 22 23 24 23 24 24 23 Breast cancer among women in Yemen is the most common type of cancer, accounting for 30.8% of the total cancer cases among women, with around 2,872 new cases recorded in 2022 [ 25 26 27 Methods Study design, setting, and population A matched case-control design was employed from June to August 2024. Female patients aged 18 years or older with newly diagnosed breast cancer (diagnosed within the past six months) who were admitted to or visited the outpatient clinics of the oncology center in Sana’a city were recruited as cases. Females with breast cancer diagnosed more than six months prior to the interview, those with metastases, or those with a history of old cancer were excluded. The oncology center is the largest of its kind in Yemen and is well-equipped to handle various types of cancer, receiving patients from all governorates across the country. For each case, two female control were selected. These controls self-reported not being diagnosed with any type of cancer or having any tumors and were matched based on age (within ± 2 years), place of residence (urban or rural), the governorate from which the cases originated, and menopausal status. The controls were selected from relatives of non-cancer patients admitted to one of the following hospitals in Sana’a city: Al-Jamhory, Al-Kwait, and Al-Thwara. With a power of 80% and an alpha level of 0.05, assuming the proportion of smokers is 0.50 among the controls and the odds ratio is 2, along with a correlation of smoking between cases and controls of 0.2, the required sample size is 120 cases and 240 controls. Accounting for a 5% nonresponse rate, the final sample size is adjusted to 127 cases and 254 controls. All cases that met the inclusion criteria and were present during the data collectors’ visits were included in the study. Data collection began with the cases until the required sample size was reached, followed by data collection from the controls. The cases in this study were from various governorates in Yemen. Due to financial and security constraints, it was difficult to select controls from the same communities. Instead, controls were chosen from the relatives of non-cancer patients admitted to hospitals, ensuring they were from the same governorates and shared similar living conditions, whether rural or urban. Data collection Data regarding breast cancer diagnosis, including the date of diagnosis, histopathology results, tumor size, and grade, were collected from the patients’ files. Demographic information, dietary habits, and lifestyle data were collected through face-to-face interviews using a structured questionnaire. A medically trained team conducted the data collection. The study includes several independent variables that provide essential demographic and behavioural related information. Education level refers to the highest formal education attained, categorized as no education, primary education, or secondary and above. Marital status indicates the current marriage status of women, including married, ex-married, and single, while work status reflects whether women are employed or unemployed. Additionally, smoking status identifies tobacco use history, dividing participants into never smokers, current smokers, and former smokers. The number of children refers to the total number of children born to a woman, categorized into groups of 0–1, 2–3, 4–5, and 6 or more children, which ties into the family size variable that denotes the total number of individuals Living in a household, classified as 1–4, 5–6, 7–8, and 9 or more members. The variable received hormone replacement therapy refers to whether women have ever received this treatment, categorized as yes or no, and oral contraceptive usage is noted with responses of no or yes. The presence of a family member with cancer is recorded either yes or no. Physical activity was assessed using the international physical activity questionnaire-short form [ 28 29 The Diet History Questionnaire II from the Canadian National Cancer Institute, designed to assess intake over the past year, was adapted for Yemeni contexts before use [ 30 31 Data analysis Causal model analysis was used to investigate the relationship between the frequency of sweet consumption and breast cancer in women. Stata version 16 was used to analyze the data, employing conditional logistic regression to account for matching. Initially, the crude odds ratio was calculated to assess the association between the main outcome (breast cancer) and the main exposure (sweet food). Bivariate analysis was then conducted to examine the association between other exposure factors and breast cancer. Variables that showed significant associations with breast cancer in the bivariate analysis were subsequently evaluated in relation to the main exposure (sweet foods). Variables that were associated with both breast cancer and sweet foods in the bivariate analysis were identified as confounders and included in the final model. The adjusted odds ratio, along with the 95% confidence interval, was estimated, and a p-value from the Likelihood ratio test of less than 0.05 was considered statistically significant. Results A total of 127 cases and 254 controls were included in this analysis. The mean age of the cases was 43.7 ± 10.2 (SD) years, and the mean age of the controls was 43.3 ± 13.1 (SD) years. Approximately 45.0% of both cases and controls resided in rural areas, and one-third of both groups were post-menopausal. Unexpectedly, the percentage of women with a secondary level of education or above was higher among the cases (29.1%) than the controls (16.1%), and this difference was statistically significant (COR, 3.21; 95% CI 1.73–5.94). 95% CI: 1.82–7.63), pan-fried bread (three to seven times per week, COR: 2.99; 95% CI: 1.50–5.98) or (one to two times per week, COR: 2.56; 95% CI: 1.46–4.46) pan-fried chicken (one to two times per week, COR: 2.97; 95% CI: 1.12–3.26), bread made from white flour (more than one time per day, COR: 2.71; 95% CI: 1.39–5.27), and soft drinks (one to two times per week, COR: 2.84; 95% CI: 1.50–5.37) were at higher risk of breast cancer compared to those who consumed these foods rarely or never. Respondents who consumed chicken (boiled, oven-broiled, or grilled/barbecued) one to three times per month (COR: 0.50; 95% CI: 0.28–0.89), fruit (frequent in its seasons, COR: 0.42; 95% CI: 0.21–0.82), and red tea (three to seven times per week, COR: 0.53; 95% CI: 0.32–0.88) had a lower cancer risk. Lastly, the consumption of meat, fish (oven-broiled, or grilled/barbecued), vegetables, pulses, whole grains, animal fats, and coffee at any frequency was not associated with breast cancer (Table 2 (0.46–1.40) 1 to 2 times per week 0.61 (0.32–1.18) 0.88 (0.43–1.81)  Family history of cancer No Ref 0.001 Ref 0.004 Yes 2.35 (1.45–3.81) 2.19 (1.27–3.78) COR CI AOR Ref Discussion Our findings revealed that frequently consumption of sweet food is a strong predicators of breast cancer in Yemen. The misconceptions among Yemeni women about the importance of certain sweets, along with the enjoyable flavors of these treats, may lead to increased consumption. This trend could contribute to a higher incidence of breast cancer in Yemen, which is already the most prevalent type of cancer in the country. Frequent consumption of sweets, particularly those high in refined sugars and unhealthy fats, may be associated with an increased risk of breast cancer through several interconnected mechanisms. One of the primary concerns is the contribution of high sugar intake to obesity [ 32 33 34 35 36 37 Our findings contribute to the existing literature by generating the hypothesis of an association between frequent consumption of sweets and breast cancer in women. This research highlights the potential health risks associated with high sugar intake, particularly within the context of traditional dietary practices. By examining the relationship between sweet consumption and breast cancer development, the importance of raising awareness among women about the nutritional implications of their dietary choices is emphasized. This finding can inform public health initiatives aimed at promoting healthier eating habits and reducing cancer risk within the population. Similarly, our study did identify a significant association between pan-fried bread and breast cancer development. Pan-fried bread, also locally known as khameer, is commonly consumed by Yemenis for breakfast. Pan-fried bread is often made from refined flours and can be high in simple carbohydrates and unhealthy fats, which may lead to increased insulin resistance and inflammation, both of which are implicated in breast cancer development. In Yemen, pan-fried bread is typically prepared in small cafes or by street vendors, and it is sometimes made at home. It is usually consumed hot, and the practice of repeatedly heating oils is common. Repeatedly heated cooking oils can produce a variety of compounds, including polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, some of which have been identified as carcinogenic [ 15 38 39 40 Our findings align with other research [ 41 43 44 45 In bivariate analysis, women who drank red tea three to seven times a week were less likely to have breast cancer compared to those who consumed it more than once a day. However, this relationship disappeared in multivariable analysis, which may be due to the strong impact of sweet food intake on breast cancer risk. This finding is similar to those from China [ 46 47 48 As a case-control study design, recall bias may occur in this study, as cases were often more likely to remember details about their exposures compared to controls. Additionally, the retrospectively self-reported data on food consumption may lead some cases and controls to inaccurately estimate their dietary frequencies. Furthermore, the study did not employ a complete dietary assessment method, which means that information on the quantities of food consumed was lacking, hindering the ability to estimate energy intake and potentially confounding the relationship between risk factors and breast cancer. Despite the fact that most sweets and other food types are traditional items that have been part of the local diet in Yemen for decades, and that dietary habits often reflect long-term patterns, there is a possibility that breast cancer may have developed many years before the interviews, as it is a slow-growing disease. Additionally, some participants may have altered their dietary habits prior to the specific timeframes asked about in the study. Consequently, potential bias may occur. To address this potential bias, further cohort studies are recommended. Some reproductive factors, such as the age at first birth, the duration of hormone replacement therapy, and family history of breast cancer, were not addressed in this study. Further research that includes these factors is needed. There is also a possibility that some controls might already have undiagnosed cancer. However, given the relatively low incidence of breast cancer in the population, the number of undiagnosed cases among the controls would be minimal and unlikely to significantly influence the results. Conclusion Frequent consumption of sweets and pan-fried bread, at rates of three to seven times per week or one to two times per week, is strongly associated with an increased risk of breast cancer among women in Yemen. Policymakers, respected donors, and non-governmental organizations should raise community awareness about the risks associated with the frequent consumption of these foods. This could be achieved through a national health education campaign utilizing various media channels, schools, and initiatives focused on nutritional and hygiene awareness. Further cohort or experimental studies that use a comprehensive assessment of dietary intake are important to establish a causal relationship between sweet food consumption and breast cancer in women. Authors’ contributions MAA conceptualized, and designed the study, trained the data collectors, analysed the data, interpreted the results, and wrote the manuscript. Funding None. Data availability The datasets used and/or analysed during the current study are available from the corresponding author on reasonable request. Declarations Ethics approval and consent to participate The study received approval from the Ethics Committee of the Faculty of Medicine and Health Sciences, Sana’a University. Permission was granted by the National Oncology Center and the hospitals in Sana’a City. Due to the high percentage of illiteracy among the respondents, verbal informed consent was obtained from both cases and controls and was documented in the presence of health workers.
